subject: RE: [junit] Classes requiring input from the terminal
msgSnippet: ... A simple refactoring: 1. Create instance-level variable out of type java.io.PrintWriter . 2. In your constructors, set out to a PrintWriter wrapping
messageBody:
Quoting Bernd <berndq@...>:

> > I was wondering if I could use junit for testing
> > programs requiring input from the terminal.
>
> better to change your programm/class so that it can be
> configured to read from any input stream.
>
> Under test it will read from an input stream controlled
> by your unit tests, in normal operation this input stream will be
> System.in

A simple refactoring:

1. Create instance-level variable "out" of type "java.io.PrintWriter".
2. In your constructors, set "out" to a PrintWriter wrapping System.out.
3. Everywhere you use System.out, change to out.
4. Add a parameter to your constructors to accept the PrintWriter as a
parameter. Change client code to pass in a PrintWriter wrapping System.out.
5. Change your constructors to set "out" using the parameter passed in from the
client code.

Congratulations! Your class no longer uses System.out directly.

Do the same for System.in, replacing it with the appropriate Reader -- say a
BufferedReader.

My text UI classes usually take a Reader and Writer. Tests become dead easy to
write: simulate user input with a StringReader or a "ListReader" (a class I
often write again and again -- I need it in a library). Collect output in a
string using StringWriter. What could be easier?
